thread.title: bmc poll results: Maharashtra civic polls results: Victory for BJP's agenda of transparency, says Devendra Fadnavis | Mumbai News - Times of India
thread.title_full: bmc poll results: Maharashtra civic polls results: Victory for BJP's agenda of transparency, says Devendra Fadnavis | Mumbai News - Times of India

author: timesofindia.indiatimes.com
title: bmc poll results: Maharashtra civic polls results: Victory for BJP's agenda of transparency, says Devendra Fadnavis | Mumbai News - Times of India
text:
NEW DELHI/MUMBAI: Maharashtra Chief Minister Devendra Fadnavis on Thursday thanked the people of the state for the success in the civic body polls and said 'the result was a huge victory for the BJP's agenda of transparency'. 

"BJP's win in Maharashtra civic polls is a result of people's acceptance of our agenda of transparency," Fadnavis said. 

"People have reposed complete in Prime Minister Narendra Modi's policies of development for all," Fadnavis said. 

The Shiv Sena emerged as the single largest party in the cash-rich BMC winning 84 seats, but the BJP remained close behind with 82 seats. 

I congratulate the entire team of @BJP4Maharashtra , CM @Dev_Fadnavis & @raosahebdanve for working tirelessly among the people. 

— Narendra Modi (@narendramodi) February 23, 2017 
Adopting a shrill anti-BJP stance, an aggressive Shiv Sena had snapped ties with the BJP ahead of the municipal elections and its leader Uddhav Thackeray had expected the Sena to win at least 100 seats, if not an outright majority. 

Fadnavis, who led the BJP campaign for the civic polls, made transparency the main plank after the two allies parted ways. 

Speaking on the break-up, Fadnavis had said his party had no qualms about fighting on lesser number of seats in the BMC elections, but was firm on transparency in the Sena-controlled civic body. 

In Pune, the BJP had launched its campaign by administering oath of "transparency, corruption-free administration and good governance" to all nominees at historic Sinhagad Fort near here. 

Hitting out at BJP's repeated remarks on transparency, Uddhav Thackeray had retorted, "When you talk of transparency, we expect a similar transparency in the state government and at the Centre."
